abstract: Declassified documents reveal Federal Judge Roger Vinson of Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court permitted National Security Agency to gather information from foreigners' emails and phone calls before Congress enacted 2007 Protect America Act; documents were given to New York Times as result of Freedom of Information lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge allowed the agency cull foreigners’ emails and phone calls without judicial preapproval before Congress authorized the spying, newly declassified papers show.
snippet: A federal judge allowed the agency cull foreigners’ emails and phone calls without judicial preapproval before Congress authorized the spying, newly declassified papers show.

keywords.value: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
keywords.name: subject

headline.main: Documents Show N.S.A.’s Wiretap Moves Before Congress’s Approval
headline.print_headline: Collection of Foreigners’ Data Began Before Congress Backed It, Papers Show
